Avenol.'Inflation of credits and depreciation of the Currency. -While the world production was checked or stopped and the annual normal increase of capital 3nd the exploitation of the world's resources are way to the destruction of human lives, machinery, houses, the result of the toil of centuries, the Governments found themselves compelled, in order to supply their war finances, to create instruments of credit. Although of various kinds, these credits are all but anticipations of the results of future work; they are acceptances by the nations whose value depends on the will and perseverance of these nations to create their equivalent in effective wealth. The difference between the present capital, impaired by the war, and the realisation of prospective work constitutes the inflation of credit. The superabundance of anticipatory tokens of wealth either in the form of bank deposits or of paper money a3 compared with real wdalth is indicated by the general rise in prices.The danger of thus giving a monetary value to prospective work resides in the facility with which such arbitrary anticipations can be multiplied. This facility, while enabling the Governments to bear the enormous burden of the war, has on the other hand unsteadied their notion of the limit imposed by the resources derived from taxation and 'tiie necessary equilibrium which should obtain between these resources and expenditure.' The more such anticipatory measures are taken to meet present expenditure, the more will the call on future Isbour beincreased increased, and the more will the rise in prices be enhanced.On the other hand, the credits th-us ' created Jyy--Grvr&rrment 3 naturally lead individuals to believe that there is a continuous increase in wealth and in abundance of available supplies. While-holders of securities with fixed interest get poorer, the iiicrease of income of those who derive their wealth from production or the possession of manufactured goods, preceeds or follows the rise in prices. This feeling of confidence in high prices and the belief that they will be maintained also destroy the notion of limit in the case of the individual citizens and encourage them to extravagance in the belief that the expenses of to-day will be covered by the increased profits of to-morrow.March 2nd, 1920.
